summary: I am a historian and archaeologist from the research master Historical Studies of Radboud University Nijmegen. I have during my master attained a specialisation in cultural history in general and the history of archaeology in particular. Furthermore, I have in this period developed a passion for public history and -archaeology, not only to make the larger public aware of 'their' past, but also because public history offers insight into how historical knowledge is constructed, processed, and used in society. Combining these aspects, I see the way people interact with history and archaeology, both in the present as well as in the past itself, as the central thread to my fascination for history and archaeology.

projects.title: 51e canonvenster: Archeologie op straat
projects.description:
The 'Canon van Nijmegen' presents the history of the city in 50 windows. As this does not cover the history of Nijmegen completely, the 'Huis van de Nijmeegse Geschiedenis' provides an opportunity for a 51st window: a changing exhibition which highlights a specific aspect of Nijmegen history. 

Within this project, I wrote the texts for one of these 51st exhibition-windows, titled 'Archeologie op straat' ('Archaeology on the streets'). This window provided information on the concept of archaeological reconstructions and visualisations, several archaeological reconstructions and visualisations visible in Nijmegen, the archaeological finds they represent, and two touristic routes tying them together. The project was initiated by the archaeology department of Nijmegen City Council.

Accompanying the exhibition was a booklet which provided an overview of all visualisations and reconstructions in Nijmegen, and their historical background and context. I also wrote the texts for this booklet.

projects.title: Nijmegen Graaft!
projects.description: 'Nijmegen Graaft!''('Nijmegen Digs!') was a public archaeology project around the former Honig-factory in Nijmegen, the historical location of the Roman city of Ulpia Noviomagus, founded in 70 CE. For a small fee, the general public could help the archaeologists digging the excavation area. In an adjacent building, a workshoproom and exhibiton area were set up aimed at this general public and on weekdays at primary- and high school students. Furthermore, each day, tours were being given around the excavation area and the adjacent neighborhood.

projects.title: Anniversary Conference: 'Het beloofde land' ('The promised land')
projects.description:
On 3 April 2014 the anniversary conference of GSV Excalibur took place around the theme 'Het beloofde land' ('The promised land'). The conference had been organised by the Conference Committee, which for the occasion was reinforced by members of other committees. The conference was set up as to not only look at the Biblical aspect of the promised land, but also take into account different aspects and interpretations. Lectures were given by, amongst others, Mr. D.van Agt, Prof. Dr P. Raedts, Dr B. Wallet and M. van Praag.

The conference committee was responsible for the contact with the speakers, as well as arrange the accomodations and the practical organisation on the day itself.

projects.description:
On 30 January 2013 the conference committee of GSV Excalibu supported by student-editors of the academic magazine Ex Tempore organised a conference on the historical views on the human body. Lectures  in the morning were followed by workshops in the afternoon. Lecturers were, amongst others: Dr G. Mak, Dr L. Munteán, Dr J. W. Brouwer, and S. A. Bultman MA.

The conference committee was responsible for the contact with the speakers, as well as arrange the accomodations and the practical organisation on the day itself. As a board member of GSV Excalibur I held final responsibility over the committee.

profile_positions.company: Radboud University Honours Academy - Beyond the Frontiers
profile_positions.description:
The research I have conducted in the context of the Honours Academy ' Beyond the Frontiers' programme centred on the archive of a nineteenth-century archaeologist, Austen Henry Layard (1817 - 1894). Layard was one of the first Western archaeologists to excavate in Mesopotamia (present-day Iraq), at the Biblical sites of Nineveh and Nimrud, amongst others. The remains he uncovered in these places were unlike anything before seen in Western European academia, where the discipline of archaeology and its forebearers had mainly focussed on Greek and Roman art, which was considered to be the highest form of art ever made.

Crucial to my research were the letters which Layard sent to, and received from, two of his immediate superiors, Sir Stratford Canning (1786 - 1880), and Sir Henry Rawlinson (1810 - 1894). These letters are part of the extensive 'Layard Papers' archive kept in the British Library in London. The focus of my research is the way Layard negotiated the position of his discoveries within the prevailing European and archaeological art-historical discourses, embodied by the more classically-trained Canning and Rawlinson. 

My research was supervised in London by Dr Ulrike Sommer of the Institute of Archaeology of University College London, while my research-master tutor Dr Nathalie de Haan also supervised my progress. The final result, the basis for a scientific article to be published, was graded an 8.5 out of 10.

volunteer_experiences.description: The Young Underground Professionals are a group of Dutch young archaeologists and archaeology-minded historians and heritage professionals with a heart for public archaeology. We share a passion for new and different approaches of public archaeology and push for this agenda as organisers of events and as thinktank.

As host, I provide the guests with information on the Second World War in and around Nijmegen in general and on the bunker specifically.
As content manager, I lead a small subgroup to keep the foundation's website and Facebook up to date, as well as explore ways to enlargen the public awareness of the bunker.

As a volunteer in the Nijmegen Archeohotspot I did basic archaeological work as part of differing large research projects. This is in a location where visitors were received and informed by me about the archaeological work itself, but also about the Roman history of the city of Nijmegen. Finally, visitors could lend me a hand in the basic archaeological work.

At the Roman Festival 2014 (31 May - 2 June), a festival during which the Roman history of Nijmegen and surroundings comes to life, I was a host and tour guide. As host I manned the entrance to the festival together with my colleagues. I also assisted across the whole festival with small jobs. On the day high- and primary schools visited the festival terrain I acted as tour guide, giving five tours across the terrain (at the 'Kops plateau, where a Roman army camp was established during their occupation of the area) for the pupils of local schools. During those tours I thaught them in simple fashion about the history of Nijmegen and of the 'Kops Plateau' in particular.
